app.ProfileNew#

Classes

Profile(name[, radius])

Holds data for one profile and references to drawn lines/scatters.

Profiling([data_accessor, polygon_manager])

Manages multiple profiles for multiple samples, with:
class app.ProfileNew.Profile(name, radius=5.0)[source]#

Bases: object

Holds data for one profile and references to drawn lines/scatters.

name#

The name of this profile (e.g. “Profile 1”).

Type:

str

x, y

Coordinates of each point in the profile.

Type:

list of float

radius#

Radius used for averaging around each point.

Type:

float

stats#

For each point, store computed stats (e.g., {‘mean’:val, ‘std’:val}).

Type:

list of dict

lines#

References to matplotlib Line2D objects (so we can remove/update them).

Type:

list

scatters#

References to matplotlib PathCollection objects or single scatter for each point.

Type:

list

class app.ProfileNew.Profiling(data_accessor=None, polygon_manager=None)[source]#

Bases: object

Manages multiple profiles for multiple samples, with:

  • Multi-sample logic ( self.profiles[sample_id][profile_name] )

  • Radius-based averaging

  • Optional mask/ROI from polygons

  • Saving/loading of profile data

profiles#

Nested dict: { sample_id: { profile_name: Profile(…) } }

Type:

dict

current_sample_id#

The sample under creation/edit.

Type:

str

current_profile_name#

The profile name under creation/edit.

Type:

str

is_active#

Whether we are in the middle of creating a new profile.

Type:

bool

temp_x, temp_y

Temporary lists that store user-clicked points before finalizing.

Type:

list

data_accessor#

A user-supplied function or reference to retrieve the 2D array for a given sample ID. E.g. data_accessor(sample_id) -> np.ndarray

Type:

callable

polygon_manager#

Reference to a PolygonManager, if you want to do ROI masking. The snippet shows how you might check if a point is inside a polygon.

Type:

object

Methods

clear_profiles(axes)

Remove all profiles from the plot (all samples).

create_new_profile(sample_id, profile_name)

Start building a new profile for a specific sample ID, with a given name.

finalize_profile(axes)

Once user right-clicks, we store the points in the final Profile object, then optionally draw a connecting line and do radius-based averaging.

find_nearest_profile_point(click_x, click_y)

Return (sample_id, profile_name, idx) for the nearest profile point if within max_dist, else (None, None, -1).

get_current_profile()

Helper to get the Profile object for current_sample_id/current_profile_name.

handle_profile_click(event, axes[, is_moving])

Called from MplCanvas when user clicks in profile mode.

handle_profile_creation_click(event, axes)

Left-click => add point, Right-click => finalize.

handle_profile_move_click(event, axes)

If user is in "move profile point" mode:

is_in_roi(x_pix, y_pix, sample_id)

Check whether the pixel (x_pix, y_pix) is inside the polygon ROI(s).

load_profiles(filepath, axes)

Load profiles from a pickle file and re-draw them on the given axes.

radius_based_averaging(profile_obj, sample_id)

For each point in the given profile, gather data from the array within radius and compute stats (mean, std, etc.).

save_profiles(filepath)

Save the current profiles to a file (using pickle).

update_profile_point(sample_id, ...)

Update a single point in the profile and re-draw line/scatter/stats.
clear_profiles(axes)[source]#

Remove all profiles from the plot (all samples).

create_new_profile(sample_id, profile_name, radius=5.0)[source]#

Start building a new profile for a specific sample ID, with a given name. Optionally set a radius for averaging.

finalize_profile(axes)[source]#

Once user right-clicks, we store the points in the final Profile object, then optionally draw a connecting line and do radius-based averaging.

find_nearest_profile_point(click_x, click_y, max_dist=1.0)[source]#

Return (sample_id, profile_name, idx) for the nearest profile point if within max_dist, else (None, None, -1).

get_current_profile()[source]#

Helper to get the Profile object for current_sample_id/current_profile_name.

handle_profile_click(event, axes, is_moving=False)[source]#

Called from MplCanvas when user clicks in profile mode.

  • If not moving => creation logic (left-click adds a point, right-click finalize)

  • If moving => pick up or place a profile point

handle_profile_creation_click(event, axes)[source]#

Left-click => add point, Right-click => finalize.

handle_profile_move_click(event, axes)[source]#

If user is in “move profile point” mode:

  1. If no point picked => find nearest point

  2. Otherwise => place it

is_in_roi(x_pix, y_pix, sample_id)[source]#

Check whether the pixel (x_pix, y_pix) is inside the polygon ROI(s). If no polygon manager or no polygons, return True (no masking). Adapt this logic to your own multi-polygon or multi-sample usage.

load_profiles(filepath, axes)[source]#

Load profiles from a pickle file and re-draw them on the given axes. We’ll recreate the lines/scatters for each loaded profile.

radius_based_averaging(profile_obj, sample_id)[source]#

For each point in the given profile, gather data from the array within radius and compute stats (mean, std, etc.). If a polygon ROI is present, only include points inside the polygon.

Returns:

stats_list – One dict per point, e.g. {‘mean’: val, ‘std’: val, ‘n’: count}

Return type:

list of dict

save_profiles(filepath)[source]#

Save the current profiles to a file (using pickle).

We’ll store a structure like:

{
    sample_id: {
        profile_name: {
            'x': [...],
            'y': [...],
            'radius': float,
            'stats': [...],
            # add any other fields you need
        },
        ...
    },
    ...
}
update_profile_point(sample_id, profile_name, point_idx, new_x, new_y, axes)[source]#

Update a single point in the profile and re-draw line/scatter/stats.
